description: Variation of Condition 10 (Opening Hours) of Planning Permission 18/14249/FUL (Variation of Condition 9 (Premises shall not be used for the purposes permitted before 9am or after 11.30pm Monday-Saturday or after 10.30pm Sundays) of planning permission 10/14795/FUL. Proposal: The premises shall not be used for the purposes hereby permitted before 8am or after 11.30pm Monday to Sunday) to not to be used before 8:00 am or after 00:30hrs Monday to Sunday
decision_conditions: The site and building works required to implement the development shall only be carried out between the hours of 09:00 and 18:00 Mondays to Fridays and between 09:00 and 13:00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers.

The materials, colour and texture of the external finish of the building shall be in accordance with the details approved ref. 11/14803/COND on 12/06/2012.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the local planning authority.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers and the visual amenities of the area.

Before the use hereby permitted commences, details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority for the effective control of fumes and odours from the premises. The scheme shall be implemented before the use commences and maintained for the duration of the use.Reason: In the interests of the amenities of the area.

The details approved ref. 11/14803/COND for acoustic insultation of the buildings shall be implemented before the buildings are first occupied and thereafter permanently retained.Reason: In order to control the noise emanating therefrom and in the interests of the residential amenities of the area.

Adequate access shall be provided for people with disabilities and retained in perpetuity, in accordance with the approved details ref. 11/14803/COND.Reason: In order that the proposed building is accessible to persons with disabilities and to comply with Section 76 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.
The premises shall not be used for the purposes hereby permitted before 08:00am or after 00:30am Monday to Sunday.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers.

The refuse storage facilities shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of the development, such facilities to be permanently retained at the site.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities.

The rating level of the noise determined by the cumulative sound emissions of the public house use hereby permitted shall be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation. The noise levels shall be determined 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade. Measurements and assessment shall be carried out in accordance with British Standard 4142:1997.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers.

The use will be carried out in accordance with the details of the Noise Management Plan ref. 11/14803/COND approved 12/06/2012.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers.

The development shall be carried out in accordance with the details of 6 cycle parking spaces ref. 11/14803/COND approved 12/06/2012. These spaces shall be provided and thereafter be permanently maintained and kept available for customer cycle parking purposes and free from obstruction at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety.

The development shall be carried out in accordance with the Travel Plan approved ref. 11/14803/COND on 12/06/2012. The Travel Plan contains a package of measures for reducing the number of vehicle trips to the site by staff and customers, an action plan with timescales for the implementation of the proposed measures, details of an ongoing programme of monitoring and review and targets for reductions in car use. The monitoring and review process shall include the submission of an annual travel plan update report for the approval of the local planning authority, containing the results of annually repeated staff travel surveys and demonstrating progress towards meeting targets.Reason: To promote the use of sustainable means of transport to and from the site.

By the time the development hereby permitted is substantially complete, pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility splays of 2.8m x 3.3m shall have been provided at the access to the rear yard between vehicles exiting the access and pedestrians, and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0m above ground level.Reason: To maintain pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility in the interest of highway safety.

All deliveries to the premises should be contained within the curtilage of the site and should not encroach onto the public highway.Reason: To ensure the development is not prejudicial to highway or pedestrian safety.

The development shall be completed in accordance with the submitted details of means of enclosure to be erected along the boundaries of the site ref 11/14803/CON and approve don 12/06/2012 and shall thereafter be permanently retained.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development.

The use shall be carried out in accordance with the submitted Delivery and Service Management Plan ref 11/14803/COND approved 12/06/2012.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with the details approved ref. 11/14803/COND on 12/06/2012.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed infill extension would be approx. 2.6m deep, finished with a flat roof, approx. 2.8m high. It would integrate with the existing rear extension and garage. The proposed infill extension would not be visible from the street scene. The proposed conversion of the garage into habitable space and associated alterations are considered acceptable and of no significant impact on the street scene. The materials proposed by the applicant would match the existing dwelling and the parapet wall over the garage would be retained. As such, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Given the modest scale of the proposal and its siting, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.  Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would comply with Policies DM9 and DM10.

The site comprises a detached dwelling.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and- The impact of the development on the significance of heritage assets.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that permission for a very similar development was recently granted under application reference 19/02935/HOU, which is extant and could still be implemented on site. The only visual changes proposed by the current application over and above the previously approved application are that the height of the parapet above the single storey side extension would be increased by 150mm and the position of the roof light in the front roof slope would be altered slightly. Officers consider that these changes would not materially alter the character and appearance of the area and so officers' previous conclusions on this matter remain unaltered. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  The single storey side extension would not project beyond either the front or rear building lines of the neighbouring property to the west and the proposed increased height is not considered to be in any way unneighbourly. The proposed changes versus the previously approved application are otherwise not considered to materially affect the amenities of neighbouring occupiers and so officers previous conclusions on this matter remain unaltered. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                 In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph  192 of the NPPF 2019 requires local planning authorities to take account of: the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation; the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality; and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.                                                                                                                     Paragraph 193 of NPPF 2019 states that when considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the assets conservation, irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts of substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.                                              Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer comment: The special architectural and historic interest of the Liverpool Road Conservation Area can be summarised as an area of individually designed detached and semi-detached houses dating from the 1850s set in a mature landscape on the edge of Richmond Park. The proposed development is, overall, considered to be a modest and proportionate form of development which would not detract from the character and appearance of the area. While the extension to the eastern side of the property would have an unusual roof form, it would be small in scale compared to the dwelling and set well back from the dwelling's front wall and further still from the highway. It would, in any case, be constructed of high quality materials and so officers do not consider that it would upset the symmetry of the dwelling or in any other way detract from the historic significance of the conservation area. To the contrary, officers consider that the proposal would preserve the character and appearance of the conservation area and would not result in any harm to its significance.In conclusion, the proposed development accords with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
The assessment has been based on the original layout of the dwellinghouse that included an attached garage. The proposed extension would require planning permission.
Condition 12 (Carriageway Demarcation and Signage) - The RBK Highways and Transportation Team have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied that this condition can now be fully discharged.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 12 (Carriageway Demarcation and Signage) of planing permission 18/10299/FUL is hereby fully discharged.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 8  (Cycle Parking), 10 (Fences), 11 (Co2 and Water Calculations) and 14 (refuse) of planing permission 17/14683/FUL is hereby fully discharged.
Condition 4 (Acoustic Report) - The RBK Environmental Health Officer has reviewed the information provided and is satisfied that this condition can now be fully discharged.
Condition 10 (Constuction Management Plan) -  The RBK Highways and Transportation Team have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied that this condition can now be fully discharged.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 4 (Acoustic Report) & 10 (Constuction Management Plan) of planning permission 19/03034/FUL are hereby fully discharged.

The proposed extension and alterations fall within the parameters of permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).
Condition 6 (Cycle facilities) - Officers have reviewed the information submitted and are satisfied this condition can be fully discharged.
Condition 7 (Refuse storage facilities) - Officers have reviewed the information submitted and are satisfied this condition can be fully discharged.

Confirmation can be in writing or by amending the plans to reflect the proposals.Note: Any documentation with the incorrect proposals will need to be resubmitted, this includes the description of works section on the application form.
